newsitem.title: JAPAN: Many Japan big banks return to profit in 96/97.
newsitem.headline: Many Japan big banks return to profit in 96/97.

text.p: Most of Japan's top 10 commercial banks survived falling stock prices and bad loan losses to emerge with reasonable profits in the last business year.
Only Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd (DKB), currently under fire for its role in a racketeer payoff scandal, reported a parent current loss of 350 billion yen ($3.01 billion).
Parent current profit at the other nine banks ranged from 95 billion yen ($818 million) by Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi Ltd to 1.04 billion yen ($8.9 million) by Hokkaido Takushoku Bank Ltd.

"We've posted our first ever loss. But since we've carried out loan write-offs actively, from 1997/98 we should be able to cope with the problem without relying on latent profits in our securities holdings," a DKB executive told reporters.
Current profit is pretax and includes gains or losses on non-operating activities such as investments in stocks.

In 1995/96, seven out of the 10 big banks -- Sakura Bank Ltd, Fuji Bank Ltd, Sakura Bank Ltd, Tokai Bank Ltd, Asahi Bank Ltd, Daiwa Bank Ltd, and Hokkaido Takushoku -- posted parent current losses as they disposed of massive problem loans.
Banks continued huge loan write-offs in 1996/97 to cover expected losses from falling domestic property prices.
The 10 banks said that they disposed of problem loans worth about 3.35 trillion yen ($28.8 billion) in 1996/97 against about 6.3 trillion yen ($54.3 billion) in 1995/96.
DKB wrote off the biggest amount of problem loans in 1996/97 -- 620 billion yen ($5.34 billion). Sakura disposed of problem loans worth 503 billion yen ($4.33 billion).
A 16 percent decline in Tokyo's stock market in 1996/97 also hit earnings.

The 10 banks expect operating profits from the banking business in 1997/98 to fall to a total of 2.32 trillion yen ($20.0 billion) from 2.7 trillion yen ($23.2 billion) in 1996/97 and 3.5 trillion yen ($30.1 billion) in 1995/96.
An expected decline in operating profits in 1997/98 reflects prospects for higher interest rates which would increase banks' funding costs, executives said.
The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is coming under growing pressure to raise interest rates as the nation's economic recovery seems fairly robust.
The discount rate has been at a record low 0.5 percent since September 8, 1995 to help economic recovery. It contributed to banks' good operating profits in 1995/96 and in 1996/97.
The 10 banks all forecast parent current profits for 1997/98.
However, financial sources said some may revise forecasts downward later, as they to try to clear up bad loans to meet stricter capital adequacy standards.

Japan is scheduled to introduce the new adequacy standards from the end of the 1997/98 business year, in order to bolster confidence in Japan's banking sector by keeping a closer watch on the quality of bank assets.
Faced with pressure to build up stronger capital positions, some big banks such as DKB, Asahi, Sanwa and Sumitomo Trust & Banking Co Ltd are expected to issue preferred stocks in 1997/98, they said.
